header.title: THE INVINCIBLE MAGICK SPELLS of The Afghan Mullah-Sensees

central_thesis: The book purports to transmit an ancient system of Afghan magical spells and signs, preserved by Mullah-Sensees for over 1400 years. This system, rooted in Islamic and local traditions, offers practical solutions for a range of human needs including love, protection, healing, and prosperity. It strictly emphasizes ethical use for benevolent purposes, warning of severe repercussions for malefic intent, and asserts the inherent power and efficacy of its methods when followed precisely.

structure_content.summary: This section outlines the ethical foundation of the Mullah-Sensees' magic, stating that spells and signs are for 'good works towards mankind' and that 'evil purposes' will 'undoubtedly backfire'. It establishes the origin of the spells in the Afghan mountains, their generational transmission, and their preservation in 'original form'. The author aims to provide insight into Afghan and Middle Asian magic, asserting the spells' proven efficacy for over 1400 years.

Focuses on spells to attract and maintain love, traditionally used by men to secure affection for up to four wives. The spells are described as 'very powerful' for winning desired love, recovering lost love, and ensuring marital fidelity. It includes a specific spell 'TO BE LOVED BY INFIDELS' (also effective on anyone), which involves holding a written sign and murmuring an incantation in Pushto (derived from Arabic/Egyptian magic) while observing the target, until a behavioral change is noted.

Details the historical materials for creating magical signs: goat skin with blue ink (olive oil and lapis-lazuli) in northern Afghanistan, and green ink (Afghan emeralds) in the south and Persia. It notes the modernization to ballpoint pen and paper due to ease, emphasizing that the 'new methods have not affected the power' as 'the important part is the symbol of the sign itself'.

structure_content.chapter_title: TO OBTAIN THE LOVE OF YOUR FOUR WIVES AND KEEP THEM FAITHFUL
structure_content.summary: Presents an Arabic spell, introduced by Moslem traders, aimed at securing and maintaining the love and fidelity of up to four wives. The ritual involves holding a specific sign (or keeping it in a wallet) and repeating the incantation three times while looking at the wives.

Describes a practice for men involving carrying a specific sign in a wallet or pocket for an hour before visiting wives. Additionally, a distinct women-only spell, originating from Yemen and referenced in the Quran, is provided. This spell requires tying nine knots in a piece of string while repeating a specific incantation.
A general section introducing various protective spells. The first is 'FOR PROTECTION FROM ATTACK', requiring the practitioner to simply 'Carry the spells with you' to guard against physical attacks.

structure_content.chapter_title: FOR PROTECTION DURING MINING AND TO PREVENT MINES CAVING IN
structure_content.summary: Provides a specific sign to be carried for protection in hazardous environments, particularly mining, aimed at preventing accidents like mine collapses.

structure_content.chapter_title: FOR PROTECTION FROM MAGIC AND EVIL THOUGHTS OF YOUR ENEMIES
structure_content.summary: Offers a protective sign intended to shield the user from both overt magical attacks and negative psychic influences or 'evil thoughts' directed by adversaries. The ritual involves carrying the specific sign.

structure_content.chapter_title: FOR INFLUENCING ALL BUSINESS AND MONEY VENTURES
structure_content.summary: A spell and corresponding sign designed to promote success in financial and business endeavors. While the specific ritual for the sign is not detailed beyond implication of carrying, the associated spell, 'ALHAMDOLILLAH RABIL AMEEN', is to be recited 'Before making business decisions'.

Details a magical healing practice involving a specific sign and incantation. The ritual requires placing the sign on the 'affected area' and repeating the healing spell three times. This section also includes five non-magical, traditional Afghan remedies for common ailments like constipation, diarrhea, common cold, back pain, and eye problems, primarily using physical pressure and rubbing techniques.

This chapter introduces spells intended for hostile applications, but opens with a severe caution: 'Do not use these spells in order to attack someone who has done you no harm.' It details a spell 'TO CAUSE CONFUSION AMONGST YOUR ENEMIES', which involves burying a specific sign in an enemy's garden and reciting an incantation. The author claims this spell will cause enemies to 'constantly fight each other rather than you'.

structure_content.chapter_title: TO CAUSE THE DEMOLITION OF STRONGHOLDS (PART ONE & TWO)
structure_content.summary: Describes a powerful, multi-part spell intended to 'lay siege to a house or stronghold and completely demolish it'. It involves three distinct signs. Part One's sign is buried in the enemy's garden or land next to their dwelling. Part Two's sign (the second of three) is buried near the stronghold's west wall. Part Three's sign (the third) is buried near the east wall. The combined ritual for 'TO LAY SIEGE TO A STRONGHOLD AND DEMOLISH IT COMPLETELY' involves burying all three signs while repeating a spell three times, with extreme warnings about fatal backfire if misused against an undeserving target.

structure_content.chapter_title: FOR PROTECTION IN BATTLE; ALSO FOR GOOD LUCK
structure_content.summary: Provides a sign for personal safety in conflict and for general good fortune. The ritual involves binding the sign 'to your head or tie to your left arm'. It is attributed to the legendary figure Solomon and is also employed as a general good luck charm.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Spell for Attracting Wealth and Good Fortune
structure_content.summary: Offers a spell and corresponding sign specifically for enhancing wealth and bringing good fortune. The ritual instruction is to say the spell 'ALHAMDOLILLAH RABIL AMEEN' before making business decisions. The sign itself, a complex grid of Arabic-like symbols, is implied to be carried or used in conjunction with the verbal spell.

key_concepts.definition: Magical healers and magicians from Afghanistan who are the traditional keepers and transmitters of the spells and signs described in the text.

Visual talismans or sigils, typically drawn patterns of Arabic or Pushto script and symbols, which are integral to the magical operations. Their symbolic form is considered the 'important part', overriding the material used for their construction.
Verbal incantations, often rooted in Islamic phrases (like Bismillah or Allah-O-Akbar) or Pushto language, which are recited in conjunction with the signs to activate their magical effect.

A foundational principle stating that the magic must only be used for 'good works' and benevolent purposes. Malicious intent or attacking those who have caused no harm is explicitly warned to result in a severe 'backfire', leading to the practitioner's own demise and internal injuries.
The emphasis on the ancient lineage (over 1400 years) and generational transmission of the spells and signs, asserting their inherent efficacy and the importance of preserving their 'original form'.

The belief that the spells and signs possess intrinsic power, independent of the materials used for their creation (e.g., modern pen and paper are as effective as traditional goat skin and special inks), provided the directions are 'followed precisely'.

practical_system.description: The Mullah-Sensee system is an operative magical tradition centered on the combination of 'signs' (hand-drawn sigils, often calligraphic) and 'spells' (verbal incantations, primarily in Arabic or Pushto). The magic is presented as inherently potent and effective, requiring precise execution of instructions and strict adherence to ethical principles, especially concerning non-maleficence. The signs serve as focal points or conduits for magical energy, while the spells are sonic activations of intent. Efficacy is not dependent on elaborate materials or complex ritual structures, making it highly accessible and adaptable.
tools: Hand-drawn 'signs' (on paper, goat skin, or other suitable material).
Writing implements (e.g., ballpoint pen, traditional ink).
A piece of string (for specific knot-tying spells).
Personal items for carrying (e.g., wallet, pocket, cloth for binding).
rituals: Holding a sign in the right hand while murmuring a spell and observing the target (e.g., love spells).
Carrying a sign on one's person (in hand, wallet, pocket, bound to head or arm) for protection, vitality, or luck.
Burying signs in specific locations (e.g., enemy's garden, near stronghold walls) for offensive or defensive purposes.
Placing a sign directly on an 'affected area' of the body while repeating a spell for healing.
Tying a specific number of knots (e.g., nine) in a piece of string while repeating an incantation for particular outcomes (e.g., female sexual vitality).
Repeating spells multiple times (e.g., three times) or continually until a desired effect is observed.

relevant_quotes.text: Information for this book was obtained on the understanding that the beliefs of the Mullah-Sensees (magical healers and magicians) are to be used for good works towards mankind. These spells and signs must not be used for evil purposes as evil will undoubtedly backfire on the user if the necessary precautions have not been taken.
Every spell contained in this book has worked for over 1400 years and will work for you if you follow the directions of the Mullah-Sensees.

To make the signs all you need is an ordinary pen and paper and draw the sign that you require. It does not matter when or where you make the sign as the important part is the symbol of the sign itself.

IF YOU USE THIS SPELL TO ATTACK A PERSON OR STRONGHOLD WHO HAS NOT HARMED YOU, I AM CERTAIN YOU WOULD DIE WITHIN A WEEK. THE SPIRITS WOULD KNOW YOU WERE THE FIRST AGGRESSOR AND AS SUCH WOULD REPEL THE SPELL BACK TO THE PERSON WHO CAST IT. YOUR BODY WOULD BE DEMOLISHED AND YOU WOULD DIE FROM INTERNAL INJURIES. THE ONLY WAY TO STOP DEATH IS TO DIG THE SIGNS UP AND BURN THEM AT THE SAME TIME SAYING: BISMILLAH-IRRAHMAN-IRRAHIIM.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work offers a unique and rare insight into a specific regional tradition of Islamic folk magic, providing primary source material on Afghan Mullah-Sensee practices. It stands apart from common Western Grimoire traditions through its emphasis on specific Arabic and Pushto incantations and distinct sigil forms. The strong ethical warnings against misuse and the concept of direct magical 'backfire' resonate with traditional magical wisdom across cultures. Its simple, accessible operative methods (pen, paper, spoken word) highlight a practical, low-barrier entry point for specific magical outcomes, making it relevant for comparative studies of operative magic and cultural expressions of esoteric belief.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes practitioners of folk magic, particularly those interested in Islamic or Middle Eastern traditions; students of comparative esotericism, anthropology of religion, or regional magical practices; and individuals seeking practical, outcome-focused magical methods for personal well-being, protection, and prosperity, provided they adhere strictly to the ethical guidelines and the instructions of the Mullah-Sensees.
